'The Big Weekend Show' panelists sound off on the Biden administration and border crisis.
The left-leaning fact check site Snopes reversed one of its rulings this weekend to admit that President Biden did, in fact, wear a construction hard hat backwards.
Biden was pictured during a visit to union workers in Wisconsin alongside Sen. Amy Klobuchar, D-Minn. The photo clearly shows Biden wearing the hard hat backwards, with the strap and tightening knob clearly visible.
Snopes' initial fact check, published Friday, attempted to explain the appearance.
"The photo is genuine. And it does look, at first glance, like Biden was wearing that hard hat backwards. But after comparing it to other photos and videos of the same event, we were forced to reach the opposite conclusion: The hat on Biden's head was facing forward, bill to the front, not backward," Snopes claimed.
DOZENS OF SENATE REPUBLICANS WARN BIDEN'S LATEST WAR ON ENERGY EMPOWERS AMERICA'S ENEMIES
The left-leaning political fact checker Snopes reversed one of its rulings this weekend to admit that President Biden did, in fact, wear a construction hard hat backwards. (Twitter @amyklobuchar)
Social media users blasted the determination, however, as hard hats universally have the tightening strap on the back. After weathering a storm on social media, Snopes offered an update reversing the fact check.
"The prevailing counter-argument is that if the suspension of the hat has been purposely configured by its owner such that the bill and tightening knob are worn to the back (as was the case of the hat Biden wore), to wear that hat with the bill facing forward is, practically speaking, to wear it backwards. Therefore, it's argued, it's actually true that, in the photo op discussed below, Biden was...[Content truncated]

Faith and Freedom coalition executive Tim Head and former Blue Dog Coalition communications director Kristen Hawn discuss the border crisis and comment on gaffes from President Biden and former President Trump.
Left-leaning fact-checker Snopes was swiftly criticized on social media Sunday after reversing its initial fact-check on a photo of President Biden wearing a hardhat backwards.¬†
Sen. Amy Klobuchar, D-Minn., posted the photo of the president to X on Thursday. Biden can be seen wearing the hardhat backwards in the photo, which went viral on social media.
Snopes' initial fact-check, published Friday, attempted to explain the appearance.
"The photo is genuine. And it does look, at first glance, like Biden was wearing that hard hat backwards. But after comparing it to other photos and videos of the same event, we were forced to reach the opposite conclusion: The hat on Biden's head was facing forward, bill to the front, not backward," Snopes claimed.
U.S. President Joe Biden speaks about funding for the I-535 Blatnik Bridge at Earth Rider Brewery on January 25, 2024, in Superior, Wisconsin. Biden touched on his economic agenda and recent federal funding for infrastructure projects.¬† (¬†(Photo by Stephen Maturen/Getty Images))
SNOPES DECLARES FAKE FLORIDA ‚ÄòANTI-WOKE BANNED BOOK LIST‚Äô TO BE SATIRE, INSTEAD OF ADMITTING IT'S JUST FALSE
Snopes' reversed the fact-check after mounting social media backlash...[Content truncated]

metatags.twitter:title: How America‚Äôs fact-checkers became Biden‚Äôs Pravda
metatags.og:title: How America‚Äôs fact-checkers became Biden‚Äôs Pravda
metatags.og:description: Snopes has been caught trying to cover-up for the president‚Äôs latest gaffe.
metatags.twitter:description: Snopes has been caught trying to cover-up for the president‚Äôs latest gaffe.

website_content.content:
[Content truncated]... had to employ an Olympics-worthy display of mental gymnastics.
‚ÄòThe photo is genuine. And it does look, at first glance, like Biden was wearing that hard hat backwards‚Äô, Snopes . ‚ÄòBut after comparing it to other photos and videos of the same event, we were forced to reach the opposite conclusion: the hat on Biden‚Äôs head was facing forward, bill to the front, not backward.‚Äô
Citing Cooper Safety Supply‚Äôs ‚ÄòHard Hat FAQ‚Äô, Snopes claimed the hat only _appeared_ to be on backwards. While Biden might have looked odd to non-experts, Snopes insisted that he was wearing the hat correctly all along. Our lying eyes had simply deceived us.
After a barrage of complaints, Snopes  barely a day later. ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs actually true that‚Ä¶ Biden was wearing it backwards‚Äô, it clarified. ‚ÄòThe strap and tightening knob, which should have been behind Biden‚Äôs head, were on his forehead.‚Äô Which was precisely what most internet users were mocking Biden for in the first place.
 #### Video ### Starmer‚Äôs one-party state #### spiked]
While the case of the backwards hard hat may be trivial in the grand scheme of things, Snopes‚Äô willingness to dissemble on the president‚Äôs behalf speaks to a broader problem for journalism and ‚Äòfact-checking‚Äô in the Biden era.
Tellingly, around the time of Biden‚Äôs inauguration in 2021, the _Washington Post_ announced that it was closing its presidential fact-checking database. Similarly, Markos Moulitsas, co-founder of Vox Media, declared how ‚Äòweird‚Äô it was ‚Äònot having to fact-check a presidential speech‚Äô as Biden was being sworn in. After the turbulence of the Trump years, and with a supposedly safe pair of hands in the White House, there would apparently be no need to check if the new president‚Äôs claims were true.
Those who pose as ‚Äòfact-checkers‚Äô today are often less interested in establishing the truth than in enforcing a particular narrative ‚Äì or defending a particular politician. Indeed, as the Snopes hard-hat debacle shows us, much of the fact-checking media has turned into Joe Biden‚Äôs very own _Pravda_.
Who will fact-check the fact-checkers?
**Thomas Osborne**¬†is an intern at¬†_spiked_.

ClaimReview.claimReviewed: Joe Biden told a factory worker "I don‚Äôt

website_content.content:
The claim: Joe Biden told a factory worker 'I don‚Äôt work for you'
-----------------------------------------------------------------
A viral social media post claims Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden isn‚Äôt the public servant he‚Äôs made out to be.
The meme, , depicts an encounter between Joe Biden and a person¬†wearing a helmet who is turned away from the camera. There‚Äôs a speech bubble over Biden‚Äôs head which reads ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt work for you!‚Äù as Biden points at the person, insinuating he said that to the person.
‚ÄúRemember this on Election Day 2020,‚Äù the text on the image reads.
The person who posted the meme, which has been shared 63,000 times, did not respond to USA TODAY‚Äôs request for comment.
**Fact check:**
Yes, Biden said that, but context is missing
--------------------------------------------
In March, Biden got into a heated exchange over gun rights with a factory worker at an auto plant in Detroit, .
‚ÄúYou‚Äôre working for me, man,‚Äù the¬†worker told Biden.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm not working for you,‚Äù Biden said. ‚ÄúGive me a break, man. Don‚Äôt be such a horse‚Äôs a--.‚Äù
But the conversation between the two before those words were exchanged provides additional context to the quote in the meme.
!
As Biden was making his way through a crowd of workers at the Fiat Chrysler...[Content truncated]

Did Biden Wear a Hard Hat Backwards in Photo Op with Construction Workers?
==========================================================================
, 
Posted on AllSides January 31st, 2024
From The Left
FACT CHECK
U.S. President Joe Biden wore a hard hat backwards during a photo op with union construction workers in Superior, Wisconsin.
Rating: True
Editor's Note:¬†We received a ton of comments in a very short time challenging our assumption that wearing a hard hat "backwards" means wearing it with the bill facing to the rear, and "forwards" means wearing it bill to the front. On the basis of that assumption, we originally rated the claim that Biden was wearing a hard hat backwards as false.
, 
-----------------------------------------------------
]
AllSides Media Bias Rating: 
*   
*   
128592/95803

Through ‚ÄúBuild America, Buy America,‚Äù Biden-Harris Administration is investing in American workers, creating good-paying, union jobs¬†

Click here to view the third installment of the Investing in America short-form video series¬†
WASHINGTON ‚Äì Today, the U.S. Department of Transportation released the third installment of its ‚ÄúInvesting in America‚Äù video series focused on the men and women producing American-made steel out of Coatesville, Pennsylvania, and the ‚ÄúBuild America, Buy America‚Äù provisions of President Biden‚Äôs Infrastructure Law. ¬†
The ‚ÄúBuild America, Buy America‚Äù Act, enacted as part of the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law, broadly requires all federally funded infrastructure projects be built with American-made iron, steel, manufactured products, and construction materials. With more than 50,000 projects underway that are funded by the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law, American workers in towns across the country are rebuilding and improving the infrastructure we count on ‚Äì roads, bridges, airports, railways, and transit systems ‚Äì with materials made right here in America.¬†
The video features members of United Steel Workers (USW) Local 1165 in Coatesville, Pennsylvania, including Brandon, a third-generation Coatesville resident, and Stacey, a USW member for more than 35 years. Steel produced at the Coatesville mill is being used in infrastructure...[Content truncated]

website_content.content:
[Content truncated]... that they don‚Äôt earn more. That they simply lack the skills they need to be paid more.
But there‚Äôs no such thing as unskilled workers. Only underpaid workers.  The problem is that their wages haven‚Äôt kept pace with their productivity.
The ‚Äúpaid what you‚Äôre worth‚Äù mythology also lures the unsuspecting into thinking nothing can be done to change what people are paid. It‚Äôs simply the way the market works.
Meanwhile, according to this same view, CEOs who rake in tens of millions and Wall Street traders who rake in hundreds of millions, are simply being paid what they‚Äôre ‚Äúworth‚Äù because that‚Äôs what the market has dictated.
Rubbish. The ‚Äúpaid what you‚Äôre worth‚Äù fairytale ignores power and disregards policies that have made inequality skyrocket. Like the demise of , which has given big corporations the power to set prices, , and reward their CEOs unprecedented . This fairytale ignores the attacks on labor unions that have reduced union membership from over  in the 1950s to .). All of this resulting in a massive shift in power and wealth from workers to owners.
Those at the top justify their staggering wealth, and they‚Äôre ‚Äúworth,‚Äù three ways:
The first is trickle-down economics. They claim that their wealth trickles down to everyone else as they invest it and create jobs. Just wait for it‚Ä¶ But as we know, wealth at the top has soared for decades and .
The second is the ‚Äúfree market.‚Äù They talk about market forces beyond their control. But remember, markets are created by rules. These rules don‚Äôt exist in nature; they are human creations. The political power of the wealthy has let them change the rules for their own benefit ‚Äî busting unions, monopolizing industries, and reaping big tax cuts.
The third is the idea that they‚Äôre superior human beings. Sure, they may be talented but this doesn‚Äôt justify the staggering amount of wealth they are now taking home. Nor does it justify the amount of wealth they will pass down to heirs. The biggest intergenerational transfer of wealth in history will occur over the  as the  hand down roughly some $36 trillion dollars to their children and grandchildren. That doesn‚Äôt make those heirs superior. It makes them lucky.
The reality is there‚Äôs no justification for today‚Äôs extraordinary concentration of wealth at the very top. Or for how little people are paid at the bottom.
The ‚Äúpaid what you‚Äôre worth‚Äù myth has proven to be a cruelly effective way to put the blame on workers for not getting ahead ‚Äî while giving the rich and powerful cover to rig the game for their own benefit.
It is distorting our politics, rigging our markets...[Content truncated]
